<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">Counties of Ireland</h1>

<area alt="County Westmeath" coords="248,210,249,210,250,210,250,210,252,211,253,212,255,214,256,215,256,216,257,218,260,219,262,220,265,222,266,222,268,223,268,224,269,225,270,225,271,225,271,223,272,222,272,220,273,222,274,224,275,225,275,227,275,229,275,230,274,232,273,233,272,234,272,235,272,237,272,239,272,240,272,241,271,242,268,243,266,246,263,248,261,249,259,250,257,252,255,253,254,255,253,256,250,258,247,260,245,262,243,262,241,261,239,261,238,261,237,262,236,261,235,258,233,255,231,253,229,254,227,255,226,256,224,257,223,257,222,257,218,257,215,258,211,259,210,259,209,260,208,259,208,255,207,252,207,248,207,247,206,245,207,245,207,246,208,246,209,247,210,247,211,246,213,246,214,246,215,246,213,245,212,244,212,242,212,240,212,239,214,239,215,238,216,238,218,238,219,237,222,238,225,238,228,238,229,238,230,237,231,236,231,234,230,233,230,231,231,229,232,226,233,224,234,222,236,221,238,219,238,217,239,215,240,213,240,214,241,215,241,216,242,215,243,215,244,215,245,214,247,214,246,213,246,211,247,210,248,210,248,210,248,210,248,210" href="/wiki/County_Westmeath" shape="poly" title="County Westmeath"></area>
<area alt="County Offaly" coords="256,253,257,252,258,251,259,250,261,252,264,253,267,254,269,258,271,262,272,267,272,268,271,269,270,271,269,272,269,273,269,274,269,275,270,277,268,277,266,277,263,278,261,279,262,279,263,280,264,281,265,281,267,282,267,282,266,282,264,282,263,282,260,282,258,283,255,283,254,284,253,284,252,283,252,281,252,280,252,278,250,277,248,276,247,275,245,276,244,277,242,277,240,278,237,279,235,280,234,281,234,283,234,284,233,285,231,285,230,286,231,288,232,289,233,291,231,293,230,294,228,295,227,297,226,299,225,301,225,302,224,304,224,306,222,306,221,305,219,305,218,307,216,308,215,310,213,312,211,314,208,316,208,317,208,318,207,320,206,318,204,316,202,314,202,313,201,312,201,311,201,309,201,308,202,307,203,305,204,303,205,301,207,299,206,297,206,295,207,293,208,292,209,290,207,289,205,288,203,287,202,286,202,284,201,283,201,282,200,281,199,281,199,280,200,279,201,278,202,277,203,275,204,274,205,272,203,272,202,271,201,270,200,269,200,267,200,267,198,266,200,265,202,263,204,262,207,260,209,259,212,259,214,258,218,257,221,257,225,257,227,255,229,254,231,253,233,255,235,258,237,261,239,261,242,261,245,262,247,260,249,258,252,257,254,256,255,254,256,253,256,253,256,253,256,253" href="/wiki/County_Offaly" shape="poly" title="County Offaly"></area>
<area alt="County Mayo" coords="85,143,86,144,86,145,87,146,90,146,93,147,96,146,101,145,106,145,110,146,114,146,118,146,120,150,121,152,124,151,125,152,125,154,124,157,126,159,127,160,129,162,127,163,127,165,127,166,130,165,132,164,135,165,137,165,140,165,142,168,145,169,143,171,142,174,140,176,138,177,137,179,137,181,139,182,141,182,143,182,146,184,148,186,151,188,154,186,157,184,160,183,161,183,164,179,164,182,164,183,165,187,163,186,160,185,161,188,160,189,159,191,161,193,162,194,160,196,158,197,156,199,153,200,154,202,154,204,153,206,156,207,158,208,159,209,158,211,159,213,156,215,154,217,152,220,151,222,148,222,147,223,144,224,141,226,138,228,137,231,136,233,135,236,135,238,133,239,131,241,129,242,126,242,123,243,122,241,120,239,118,237,116,236,114,234,111,234,108,234,105,234,102,235,101,233,100,232,98,230,95,230,92,229,88,228,86,229,83,230,80,229,78,228,77,227,75,226,73,225,74,222,74,220,74,217,76,214,76,211,75,208,78,211,79,211,81,210,83,209,85,210,88,210,90,208,94,209,95,208,98,209,97,206,97,204,95,203,97,202,100,201,98,199,97,198,97,194,95,197,94,198,92,198,91,196,89,196,85,196,83,199,79,199,77,200,76,198,75,197,75,194,75,192,77,190,78,188,80,189,82,190,81,188,80,186,79,184,79,182,77,180,76,178,77,176,80,175,80,173,81,170,81,169,79,169,77,169,77,172,76,173,74,173,71,174,73,171,74,170,74,168,73,166,71,165,73,163,74,161,72,160,71,159,70,158,68,158,68,161,66,162,65,164,65,165,65,167,64,169,64,171,62,171,59,171,58,170,60,168,61,167,63,166,62,164,61,162,62,159,62,157,65,157,65,156,63,155,62,153,66,154,65,151,65,149,67,148,68,147,70,146,71,148,72,149,74,150,74,153,74,155,73,157,76,158,77,159,78,157,78,154,81,153,82,152,85,155,85,154,85,151,84,149,83,147,82,145,83,144,85,143,85,143,85,143,85,143" href="/wiki/County_Mayo" shape="poly" title="County Mayo"></area>
<area alt="County Mayo" coords="57,177,58,178,59,178,59,179,59,182,62,181,63,180,65,179,67,177,67,180,68,182,71,181,72,182,72,186,73,189,72,193,71,195,72,197,70,198,68,198,68,195,68,193,67,193,65,193,65,191,66,188,64,188,62,188,60,188,59,186,57,187,55,186,54,188,52,187,50,187,50,184,52,184,53,183,56,184,56,182,57,180,55,178,57,177,57,177,57,177,57,177" href="/wiki/County_Mayo" shape="poly" title="County Mayo"></area></map><img alt="A map of Ireland showing traditional county borders and names with Northern Ireland counties colored tan, all other counties colored green" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="400" height="500" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg/400px-Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg/600px-Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg/800px-Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg.png 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_1_1708831943" width="400"/></div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ireland_trad_counties_named.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The 32 traditional counties of Ireland.<br/>
<small>The traditional county of Dublin is now subdivided into 4 administrative counties.</small></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <b>counties of Ireland</b> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>contaetha na h√âireann</i></span>; <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects" title="Ulster Scots dialects">Ulster-Scots</a>: <i>coonties o Airlann</i>) are sub-national divisions that have been, and in some cases continue to be, used to geographically demarcate areas of local government. These land divisions were formed following the <a href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland" title="Norman invasion of Ireland">Norman invasion of Ireland</a> in imitation of the <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">counties</a> then in use as units of local government in the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> The older term "<a href="/wiki/Shire" title="Shire">shire</a>" was historically equivalent to "county". The principal function of the county was to impose royal control in the areas of taxation, security and the <a href="/wiki/Administration_of_justice" title="Administration of justice">administration of justice</a> at the local level. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cambro-Norman" title="Cambro-Norman">Cambro-Norman</a> control was initially limited to the southeastern parts of Ireland; a further four centuries elapsed before the entire island was shired. At the same time, the now obsolete concept of <a href="/wiki/County_corporate" title="County corporate">county corporate</a> elevated a small number of towns and cities to a status which was deemed to be no less important than the existing counties in which they lay. This double control mechanism of 32 counties plus 10 counties corporate remained unchanged for a little over two centuries until the early 19th century, since then counties have been adapted and in some cases divided by legislation to meet new administrative and political requirements.</p>
<p>The powers exercised by the Cambro-Norman barons and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_English_(Ireland)" title="Old English (Ireland)">Old English</a> nobility waned over time. New offices of political control came to be established at a county level. In the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a>, some counties have been split resulting in the creation of new counties. Along with certain defined cities, counties still form the basis for the demarcation of areas of <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Local government in the Republic of Ireland">local government in the Republic of Ireland</a>. Currently, there are 26 county level, 3 city level and 2 city and county entities ‚Äì the modern equivalent of counties corporate ‚Äì that are used to demarcate areas of local government in the Republic.</p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Counties of Northern Ireland">counties</a> are no longer used for local government; <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Local government in Northern Ireland">districts</a> are instead used. Upon the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of Ireland</a> in 1921, the county became one of the basic land divisions employed, along with county boroughs.</p>
<p></p>
<div class="toc" id="toc">
<div id="toctitle">

<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Terminology">Terminology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Terminology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The word "county" has come to be used in different senses for different purposes. In common usage, many people have in mind the 32 counties that existed prior to 1838 ‚Äì the so-called traditional counties. However, in official usage in the Republic of Ireland, the term often refers to the 28 modern counties. The term is also conflated with the 31 areas currently used to demarcate areas of <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Local government in the Republic of Ireland">local government in the Republic of Ireland</a> at the level of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="NUTS of the Republic of Ireland">LAU 1</a>.</p>
<p>In Ireland, usage of the word <i>county</i> nearly always comes before rather than after the county name; thus "<a href="/wiki/County_Roscommon" title="County Roscommon"><i>County</i> Roscommon</a>" in Ireland as opposed to "<a href="/wiki/Roscommon_County,_Michigan" title="Roscommon County, Michigan">Roscommon <i>County</i></a>" in <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>, United States. The former "King's County" and "Queen's County" were exceptions; these are now <a href="/wiki/County_Offaly" title="County Offaly">County Offaly</a> and <a href="/wiki/County_Laois" title="County Laois">County Laois</a>, respectively. The <a href="/wiki/Abbreviation" title="Abbreviation">abbreviation</a> Co. is used, as in "Co. Roscommon". A further exception occurs in the case of those counties created after 1994 which often drop the word <i>county</i> entirely, or use it after the name; thus for example internet search engines show many more uses (on Irish sites) of "<a href="/wiki/Fingal" title="Fingal">Fingal</a>" than of either "County Fingal" or "Fingal County". There appears to be no official guidance in the matter, as even the local council uses all three forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> In informal use, the word <i>county</i> is often dropped except where necessary to distinguish between county and town or city; thus "Offaly" rather than "County Offaly", but "County Antrim" to distinguish it from Antrim town. The synonym <i><a href="/wiki/Shire" title="Shire">shire</a></i> is not used for Irish counties, although the <a href="/wiki/Marquess_of_Downshire" title="Marquess of Downshire">Marquessate of Downshire</a> was named in 1789 after <a href="/wiki/County_Down" title="County Down">County Down</a>.</p>
<p>Parts of some towns and cities were exempt from the jurisdiction of the counties that surrounded them. These towns and cities had the status of a <a href="/wiki/County_corporate" title="County corporate">County corporate</a>, many granted by Royal Charter, which had all the judicial, administrative and revenue raising powers of the regular counties.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Norman_divisions_of_Ireland">Pre-Norman divisions of Ireland</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Pre-Norman divisions of Ireland">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Political_geography" title="Political geography">political geography</a> of Ireland can be traced with some accuracy from the 6th century. At that time Ireland was divided into a patchwork of <a href="/wiki/Petty_kingdom" title="Petty kingdom">petty kingdoms</a> with a fluid political hierarchy which, in general, had three traditional grades of king. The lowest level of political control existed at the level of the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuath" title="Tuath">tuath</a></i> (pl. <i>tuatha</i>). A <i>tuath</i> was an autonomous group of people of independent political jurisdiction under a <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=R%C3%AD_t%C3%BAaithe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="R√≠ t√∫aithe (page does not exist)">r√≠ t√∫aithe</a>, that is, a local petty king.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> About 150 such units of government existed. Each <i>r√≠ tuaithe</i> was in turn subject to a regional or "over-king" <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>ruiri</i></span>. There may have been as many as 20 genuine <a href="/wiki/R%C3%AD#Ruiri" title="R√≠">ruiri</a> in Ireland at any time.</p>
<p>A "king of over-kings" <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>r√≠ ruirech</i></span> was often a provincial (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>r√≠ c√≥icid</i></span>) or semi-provincial king to whom several ruiri were subordinate. No more than six genuine <a href="/wiki/R%C3%AD#R.C3.AD_ruirech" title="R√≠">r√≠ ruirech</a> were ever contemporary. Usually, only five such "king of over-kings" existed contemporaneously and so are described in the <a href="/wiki/Irish_annals" title="Irish annals">Irish annals</a> as <i>fifths</i> (<i>c√∫ig√≠</i> in <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>). The areas under the control of these kings were¬†: <a href="/wiki/Ulster" title="Ulster">Ulster</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>Ulaidh</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Leinster" title="Leinster">Leinster</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>Laighin</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Connacht" title="Connacht">Connacht</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>Connachta</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Munster" title="Munster">Munster</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>An Mhumhan</i></span>) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mide" title="Mide">Mide</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>An Mh√≠dhe</i></span>). Later record-makers dubbed them <i>provinces</i>, in imitation of <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman provinces</a>. In the Norman period, the historic fifths of Leinster and Meath gradually merged, mainly due to the impact of <a href="/wiki/The_Pale" title="The Pale">the Pale</a>, which straddled both, thereby forming the present-day province of Leinster.</p>
<p>The use of <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland" title="Provinces of Ireland">provinces</a> as divisions of political power was supplanted by the system of counties after the Norman invasion. In modern times clusters of counties have been attributed to certain provinces but these clusters have no <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Law_of_Ireland" title="Law of Ireland">legal status</a>. They are today seen mainly in a sporting context, as Ireland's four professional rugby teams play under the names of the provinces, and the <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association" title="Gaelic Athletic Association">Gaelic Athletic Association</a> has separate <a href="/wiki/GAA_provincial_council" title="GAA provincial council">Provincial councils</a> and <a href="/wiki/Provincial_championships" title="Provincial championships">Provincial championships</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Norman_areas_of_control">Norman areas of control</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Norman areas of control">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<table class="toccolours" style="float:right;margin-left:1em; clear:right">
<tr>
<th style="padding:0 5px; background-color:#ccf; font-size:111%;">

</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>

</div>
<div class="NavFrame">
<div class="NavHead" style="background-color:#ccf;border:1px solid #000000;padding: 0px 0px 0px 4px; font-size: 100%; text-align:left;margin:0px;color:#330000"><b><span style="color:black">Economy¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†</span></b></div>
<div class="NavContent" style="text-align:left;margin:0px 1px;border:none;text-weight:bold;display:none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Telecommunications in the Republic of Ireland">Communications</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Economy of the Republic of Ireland">Economy</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Taxation in the Republic of Ireland">Taxation</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Ireland" title="Transport in Ireland">Transport</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="NavFrame">
<div class="NavHead" style="background-color:#ccf;border:1px solid #000000;padding: 0px 0px 0px 4px; font-size: 100%; text-align:left;margin:0px;color:#330000"><b><span style="color:black">General</span></b></div>
<div class="NavContent" style="text-align:left;margin:0px 1px;border:none;text-weight:bold;display:none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Ireland" title="Architecture of Ireland">Architecture</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ireland" title="Geography of Ireland">Geography</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Ireland" title="History of Ireland">History</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_Defence_Forces" title="Irish Defence Forces">Military</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Recycling_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Recycling in the Republic of Ireland">Recycling</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="NavFrame">
<div class="NavHead" style="background-color:#ccf;border:1px solid #000000;padding: 0px 0px 0px 4px; font-size: 100%; text-align:left;margin:0px;color:#330000"><b><span style="color:black">Society</span></b></div>
<div class="NavContent" style="text-align:left;margin:0px 1px;border:none;text-weight:bold;display:none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Demographics of the Republic of Ireland">Demographics</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Education in the Republic of Ireland">Education</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Healthcare in the Republic of Ireland">Health care</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ireland" title="Languages of Ireland">Languages</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Media_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Media of the Republic of Ireland">Media</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="NavFrame">
<div class="NavHead" style="background-color:#ccf;border:1px solid #000000;padding: 0px 0px 0px 4px; font-size: 100%; text-align:left;margin:0px;color:#330000"><b><span style="color:black">Politics</span></b></div>
<div class="NavContent" style="text-align:left;margin:0px 1px;border:none;text-weight:bold;display:none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Law of the Republic of Ireland">Law</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Law enforcement in the Republic of Ireland">Law enforcement</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Politics of the Republic of Ireland">Politics</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Foreign relations of the Republic of Ireland">Foreign relations</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="NavFrame">
<div class="NavHead" style="background-color:#ccf;border:1px solid #000000;padding: 0px 0px 0px 4px; font-size: 100%; text-align:left;margin:0px;color:#330000"><b><span style="color:black">Policies</span></b></div>
<div class="NavContent" style="text-align:left;margin:0px 1px;border:none;text-weight:bold;display:none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Abortion in the Republic of Ireland">Abortion</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Same-sex marriage in the Republic of Ireland">Marriage equality</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div style="font-size: 100%"></div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="padding:0 5px; text-align:right;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Life_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Template:Life in the Republic of Ireland"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Life_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Template talk:Life in the Republic of Ireland"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Life_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>With the arrival of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cambro-Norman" title="Cambro-Norman">Cambro-Norman</a> knights in 1169, the <a href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland" title="Norman invasion of Ireland">Norman invasion of Ireland</a> commenced. This was followed in 1172 by the invasion of King <a href="/wiki/Henry_II_of_England" title="Henry II of England">Henry II of England</a>, commencing English royal involvement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[nb 1]</a></sup> The English governed Ireland using a structure similar to that used in England, by dividing the country into shires or counties in the late 12th and early 13th centuries.</p>
<p>In general, counties were made by amalgamating various smaller Irish territories which suited the colonial administration at the time and had little basis in older tribal boundaries. In many cases, this involved dividing an Irish territory in two. For example, the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/U%C3%AD_Maine" title="U√≠ Maine">U√≠ Maine</a> was split to form south <a href="/wiki/County_Roscommon" title="County Roscommon">County Roscommon</a> and most of east <a href="/wiki/County_Galway" title="County Galway">County Galway</a>. Many of the counties of Ulster roughly correspond to the territories controlled by the principal clan in that particular area such as the O Donnells of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%ADr_Chonaill" title="T√≠r Chonaill">T√≠r Chonaill</a> whose political power was concentrated in what would become the County of Donegal.</p>
<p>The counties evolved over time, with the earliest defined being set out by King John, including a then much larger County Dublin. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sir_John_Davies" title="Sir John Davies">Sir John Davies</a> wrote <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup> ‚ÄòTrue it is that King John made twelve shires in Leinster and Munster‚Äînamely, <a href="/wiki/County_Dublin" title="County Dublin">Dublin</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Kildare" title="County Kildare">Kildare</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Meath" title="County Meath">Meath</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Louth" title="County Louth">Urial or Louth</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Carlow" title="County Carlow">Catherlogh</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Kilkenny" title="County Kilkenny">Kilkenny</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Wexford" title="County Wexford">Wexford</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Waterford" title="County Waterford">Waterford</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Cork" title="County Cork">Cork</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Limerick" title="County Limerick">Limerick</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Kerry" title="County Kerry">Kerry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/County_Tipperary" title="County Tipperary">Tipperary</a>. Yet these counties did stretch no further than the lands of the English colonies did extend.‚Äô In the Anglo-Saxon controlled territories, a royal official known as a "shire <a href="/wiki/Reeve_(England)" title="Reeve (England)">reeve</a>" or <a href="/wiki/Sheriff" title="Sheriff">sheriff</a> governed the shire. Large parts in the south east of the island had been shired by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cambro-Norman" title="Cambro-Norman">Cambro-Norman</a> overlords by the end of the 13th century. Following the resurgence in the 14th and 15th centuries of the <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_nobility_of_Ireland" title="Gaelic nobility of Ireland">Gaelic nobility</a>, the project was suspended, not to be resumed until the mid 16th century by the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Tudor" title="House of Tudor">House of Tudor</a>. There were two phases in this period under the newly created <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">Kingdom of Ireland</a>: the plantation of the midlands under Mary I and the plantation of <a href="/wiki/Munster" title="Munster">Munster</a> under her half-sister, Elizabeth I. By the reign of King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" title="James I of England">James I &amp; VI</a>, the process was completed with the plantation of the last remaining princely domains in the <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland" title="Provinces of Ireland">province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ulster" title="Ulster">Ulster</a>. With the late addition of <a href="/wiki/County_Wicklow" title="County Wicklow">County Wicklow</a>, the number of <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">counties</a> (<a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>: <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>contae</i></span> or <span lang="ga" xml:lang="ga"><i>condae</i></span> <small>IPA:¬†</small><span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Irish" title="Help:IPA for Irish">[Ààk ändeÀê]</a></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OxCompIrHist_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-OxCompIrHist-6">[5]</a></sup> stood at thirty two. This number remained fixed for a little over 200 years until the division of some counties into smaller entities for judicial purposes (1836), initially, followed by complete division in the 20th and 21st centuries.</p>
<p>By 1200 there were also <b>shires</b> of <a href="/wiki/Connacht" title="Connacht">Connacht</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Cork" title="County Cork">Cork</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Kerry" title="County Kerry">Kerry</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Limerick" title="County Limerick">Limerick</a>, Louth and <a href="/wiki/County_Tipperary" title="County Tipperary">Tipperary</a>. Waterford, Kilkenny and Wexford apparently date from this time, too, as remnants of <a href="/wiki/Richard_de_Clare,_2nd_Earl_of_Pembroke" title="Richard de Clare, 2nd Earl of Pembroke">Strongbow</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palatine_county" title="Palatine county">palatine county</a> in <a href="/wiki/Leinster" title="Leinster">Leinster</a>. The process continued over time, and in 1206, for example, a special commission was used to determine borders in the Munster area.</p>
<p>The County of Roscommon was separated from Connacht before 1292, and the first session of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Ireland" title="Parliament of Ireland">Parliament of Ireland</a> in 1297 created the new shires of <a href="/wiki/County_Kildare" title="County Kildare">County Kildare</a>, Meath and Ulster. Carlow, then larger than today, and extending to and including coastal <a href="/wiki/Arklow" title="Arklow">Arklow</a>, probably dates from around 1306.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roche_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-roche-7">[6]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the 14th century, "Counties of the Cross" emerged, consisting of scattered areas of church land within the existing divisions. Unlike the secular counties (or liberties), the counties of the cross were administered by royally-appointed sheriffs.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tudor_areas_of_control">Tudor areas of control</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Tudor areas of control">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Tudor" title="House of Tudor">Tudor</a> administrations finalised the division of Ireland into counties. Westmeath was separated from Meath (often <i>East Meath</i>) in 1543. Queen <a href="/wiki/Mary_I_of_England" title="Mary I of England">Mary I of England</a> introduced a new policy to pacify the midland areas ‚Äì <a href="/wiki/Plantations_of_Ireland" title="Plantations of Ireland">plantation</a>. In 1556 <a href="/wiki/County_Offaly" title="County Offaly">King's County</a> and <a href="/wiki/County_Laois" title="County Laois">Queen's County</a> were created and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Connacht" title="Kingdom of Connacht">Kingdom of Connacht</a> was broken up into the counties of Galway, Mayo and Sligo, while Leitrim was separated from Roscommon in 1565. At the same time County Clare was created and moved from Munster to Connacht, being returned to Munster in 1602.</p>
<p>In 1583 County Longford was formed from part of Westmeath and transferred to the Province of Connacht.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Province of Ulster was the last to be shired. The counties of Antrim and Down originated early in the 16th century. These were joined in 1584/5 by the counties of Armagh, Coleraine, Donegal, Fermanagh, Monaghan and Tyrone. County Cavan was also formed in 1584 and transferred from Connacht to Ulster.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roche_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-roche-7">[6]</a></sup> County Londonderry was incorporated in 1613 from the merger of County Coleraine with the barony of <a href="/wiki/Loughinsholin" title="Loughinsholin">Loughinsholin</a> (in County Tyrone), the <a href="/wiki/North_West_Liberties_of_Londonderry" title="North West Liberties of Londonderry">North West Liberties of Londonderry</a> (in County Donegal), and the <a href="/wiki/North_East_Liberties_of_Coleraine" title="North East Liberties of Coleraine">North East Liberties of Coleraine</a> (in County Antrim).</p>
<p>The last county to be formed was <a href="/wiki/County_Wicklow" title="County Wicklow">County Wicklow</a> in 1606‚Äì07, taking in the southern part of Dublin (with the exception of three "islands," exclaves of (mainly) church property), and the northern part of "Catherlough" or Carlow, including <a href="/wiki/Arklow" title="Arklow">Arklow</a>.</p>
<p>Areas that were shired by 1607 and continued in existence down to the local government reforms of 1836, 1898 and 2001 are sometimes referred to as "traditional" or "historic" counties. These areas were separate from the <a href="/wiki/County_corporate" title="County corporate">county corporates</a> that existed in some of the larger towns and cities although linked to the county at large for other purposes. From 1898 to 2001, areas with county councils were known as <a href="/wiki/Administrative_county#Ireland" title="Administrative county">administrative counties</a> while the counties corporate were designated as <a href="/wiki/County_borough" title="County borough">county boroughs</a>. In other cases, the "traditional" county was divided to form two administrative counties. From 2001, certain administrative counties, which were originally "traditional" counties, underwent further splitting.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Former_counties">Former counties</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Former counties">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Former counties include: <a href="/wiki/County_Coleraine" title="County Coleraine">County Coleraine</a>, which formed the basis of County Londonderry, the counties of <a href="/wiki/County_of_Nether_Tyrone" title="County of Nether Tyrone">Nether</a> and <a href="/wiki/County_of_Upper_Tyrone" title="County of Upper Tyrone">Upper Tyrone</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/County_Desmond" title="County Desmond">Desmond</a> which was, in 1606, split between counties Cork and Kerry. Other names seen on old maps include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caterlaugh" title="Caterlaugh">Caterlaugh</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caterlagh" title="Caterlagh">Caterlagh</a>, archaic designations of County Carlow, in the days before much of the north of that county was taken into Wicklow in the early 17th century.</p>
<p>In 1333, the <a href="/wiki/Earldom_of_Ulster" title="Earldom of Ulster">Earldom of Ulster</a> consisted of seven counties: <a href="/wiki/County_Antrim" title="County Antrim">Antrim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newtownards" title="Newtownards">Blathewyc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carrickfergus" title="Carrickfergus">Cragferus</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Coleraine" title="County Coleraine">Coulrath</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ards_(territory)" title="Ards (territory)">del Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Down" title="County Down">Dun</a> (also known as <a href="/wiki/Lecale" title="Lecale">Ladcathel</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Twescard" title="Twescard">Twescard</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bardon2005pg45_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bardon2005pg45-10">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DownII_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-DownII-11">[10]</a></sup></p>
<p>Carrickfergus would lose its county town status in 1777. Twescard is preserved as the name of a school house at <a href="/wiki/Campbell_College" title="Campbell College">Campbell College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belfast" title="Belfast">Belfast</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sub-divisions_of_counties">Sub-divisions of counties</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Sub-divisions of counties">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>To correspond with the subdivisions of the English shires into honours or <a href="/wiki/Barony" title="Barony">baronies</a>, Irish counties were granted out to the Anglo-Norman noblemen in <a href="/wiki/Cantred" title="Cantred">cantreds</a>, later known as <a href="/wiki/Barony_(Ireland)" title="Barony (Ireland)">baronies</a>, which in turn were subdivided, as in England, into <a href="/wiki/Civil_parishes_in_Ireland" title="Civil parishes in Ireland">parishes</a>. Parishes were composed of <a href="/wiki/Townland" title="Townland">townlands</a>. However, in many cases, these divisions correspond to earlier, pre-Norman, divisions. While there are 331<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2007)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> baronies in Ireland, and more than a thousand <a href="/wiki/Civil_parishes_in_Ireland" title="Civil parishes in Ireland">civil parishes</a>, there are around sixty thousand townlands that range in size from one to several thousand hectares. Townlands were often traditionally divided into smaller units called <i>quarters</i>, but these subdivisions are not legally defined.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Counties_corporate">Counties corporate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Counties corporate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The following towns/cities had charters specifically granting them the status of a <a href="/wiki/County_corporate" title="County corporate">county corporate</a>:</p>
<ul>
<li>County of the Town of <a href="/wiki/Carrickfergus" title="Carrickfergus">Carrickfergus</a> (by 1325)</li>
<li>County of the City of <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a> (1608)</li>
<li>County of the Town of <a href="/wiki/Drogheda" title="Drogheda">Drogheda</a> (1412)</li>
<li>County of the City of <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a> (1548)</li>
<li>County of the Town of <a href="/wiki/Galway" title="Galway">Galway</a> (1610)</li>
<li>County of the City of <a href="/wiki/Kilkenny" title="Kilkenny">Kilkenny</a> (1610)</li>
<li>County of the City of <a href="/wiki/Limerick" title="Limerick">Limerick</a> (1609)</li>
<li>County of the City of <a href="/wiki/Waterford" title="Waterford">Waterford</a> (1574)</li>
</ul>
<p>The only entirely new counties created in 1898 were the county boroughs of Londonderry and Belfast. Carrickfergus, Drogheda and Kilkenny were abolished; Galway was also abolished, but recreated in 1986.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Exceptions_to_the_county_system_of_control">Exceptions to the county system of control</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Exceptions to the county system of control">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Regional presidencies of Connacht and Munster remained in existence until 1672, with special powers over their subsidiary counties. Tipperary remained a <a href="/wiki/County_palatine" title="County palatine">county palatine</a> until the passing of the <a href="/wiki/County_Palatine_of_Tipperary_Act_1715" title="County Palatine of Tipperary Act 1715">County Palatine of Tipperary Act 1715</a>, with different officials and procedures from other counties. At the same time, Dublin, until the 19th century, had ecclesiastical liberties with rules outside those applying to the rest of Dublin city and county. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exclaves" title="Exclaves">Exclaves</a> of the county of Dublin existed in counties Kildare and Wicklow. At least eight other enclaves of one county inside another, or between two others, existed. The various enclaves and exclaves were merged into neighbouring and surrounding counties, primarily in the mid-19th century under a series of Orders in Council.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_of_functions">Evolution of functions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Evolution of functions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Ireland" title="Church of Ireland">Church of Ireland</a> exercised functions at the level of civil parish that would later be exercised by county authorities. Vestigial feudal power structures of major old estates remained well into the 18th century. Urban corporations operated individual royal charters. Management of counties came to be exercised by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Jury" title="Grand Jury">grand juries</a>. Members of grand juries were the local payers of <a href="/wiki/Rates_(tax)" title="Rates (tax)">rates</a> who historically held judicial functions, taking maintenance roles in regard to roads and bridges, and the collection of "county cess" taxes. They were usually composed of wealthy "country gentlemen" (i.e. landowners, farmers and merchants):</p>
<blockquote>
<p>A country gentleman as a member of a Grand Jury...levied the local taxes, appointed the nephews of his old friends to collect them, and spent them when they were gathered in. He controlled the boards of guardians and appointed the dispensary doctors, regulated the diet of paupers, inflicted fines and administered the law at petty sessions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[11]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<p>The counties were initially used for judicial purposes, but began to take on some governmental functions in the 17th century, notably with grand juries.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_and_20th_centuries">19th and 20th centuries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 19th and 20th centuries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1836, the use of counties as local government units was further developed, with grand-jury powers extended under the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_Jury_(Ireland)_Act_1836&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Grand Jury (Ireland) Act 1836 (page does not exist)">Grand Jury (Ireland) Act 1836</a>. The traditional county of <a href="/wiki/County_Tipperary" title="County Tipperary">Tipperary</a> was split into two judicial counties (or <a href="/wiki/Riding_(country_subdivision)" title="Riding (country subdivision)">ridings</a>) following the establishment of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assize_court" title="Assize court">assize courts</a> in 1838. Also in that year, local poor law boards, with a mix of magistrates and elected "guardians" took over the health and social welfare functions of the grand juries.</p>
<p>Sixty years later, a more radical reorganisation of local government took place with the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_(Ireland)_Act_1898" title="Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898">Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898</a>. This Act established a county council for each of the thirty-three Irish administrative counties. Elected county councils took over the powers of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_jury" title="Grand jury">grand juries</a>.The boundaries of the traditional counties changed on a number of occasions. The 1898 Act changed the boundaries of Counties <a href="/wiki/County_Galway" title="County Galway">Galway</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Clare" title="County Clare">Clare</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Mayo" title="County Mayo">Mayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roscommon" title="Roscommon">Roscommon</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Sligo" title="County Sligo">Sligo</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Waterford" title="County Waterford">Waterford</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Kilkenny" title="County Kilkenny">Kilkenny</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Meath" title="County Meath">Meath</a> and <a href="/wiki/County_Louth" title="County Louth">Louth</a>, and others. County Tipperary was divided into two regions: <a href="/wiki/North_Tipperary" title="North Tipperary">North Riding</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Tipperary" title="South Tipperary">South Riding</a>. Areas of the cities of Belfast, Cork, Dublin, Limerick, Derry and Waterford were carved from their surrounding counties to become <a href="/wiki/County_borough" title="County borough">county boroughs</a> in their own right and given powers equivalent to those of administrative counties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup></p>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1920" title="Government of Ireland Act 1920">Government of Ireland Act 1920</a>, the island was partitioned between <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ireland_(1921%E2%80%9322)" title="Southern Ireland (1921‚Äì22)">Southern Ireland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>. For the purposes of the Act,</p>
<blockquote>
<p>... Northern Ireland shall consist of the parliamentary counties of Antrim, Armagh, Down, Fermanagh, Londonderry and Tyrone, and the parliamentary boroughs of Belfast and Londonderry, and Southern Ireland shall consist of so much of Ireland as is not comprised within the said parliamentary counties and boroughs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<p>The county and county borough borders were thus used to determine the line of partition. Southern Ireland shortly afterwards became the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a>. This partition was entrenched in the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty" title="Anglo-Irish Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a>, which was ratified in 1922, by which the Irish Free State left the United Kingdom with <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> making the decision to not separate two days later.</p>
<p>Under the Local Government Provisional Order Confirmation Act 1976, part of the urban area of <a href="/wiki/Drogheda" title="Drogheda">Drogheda</a>, which lay in County Meath, was transferred to County Louth on 1 January 1977. This resulted in the land area of County Louth increasing slightly at the expense of County Meath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[16]</a></sup> The possibility of a similar action with regard to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waterford_City" title="Waterford City">Waterford City</a> has been raised in recent years, though opposition from Kilkenny has been strong.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_usage">Current usage</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Current usage">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_Republic_of_Ireland">In the Republic of Ireland</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: In the Republic of Ireland">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="hatnote" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Local government in the Republic of Ireland">Local government in the Republic of Ireland</a></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox vcard" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">
<tr>
<th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em">
<div class="adr" style="font-size:smaller"><span class="fn org country-name"><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a></span></div>
</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg" title="Coat of arms of Ireland"><img alt="Coat of arms of Ireland" data-file-height="830" data-file-width="640" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg/100px-Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg/150px-Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg/200px-Coat_of_arms_of_Ireland.svg.png 2x" width="100"/></a></td>
</tr>

the Republic of Ireland</a></span></td>

<div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:left;">
<ul>

</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0">

<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ireland%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Ireland‚ÄìUnited Kingdom relations">Ireland‚ÄìUnited Kingdom relations</a>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</div>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<div class="hlist" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;font-weight:normal;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_political_science#Politics_by_region" title="Outline of political science">Other countries</a></li>
<li><a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="commons:Atlas of the Republic of Ireland">Atlas</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Politics_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Template:Politics of the Republic of Ireland"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Politics_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Template talk:Politics of the Republic of Ireland"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Politics_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>In the Republic of Ireland the traditional counties are, in general, the basis for local government, planning and community development purposes, are governed by <a href="/wiki/County_council" title="County council">county councils</a> and are still generally respected for other purposes. Administrative borders have been altered to allocate various towns (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Bray" title="Bray">Bray</a>) exclusively into one county having been originally split between two counties.</p>
<p>There are now 26 county councils, three city councils and two city and county councils ‚Äì a total of 31 local government entities.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/County_Tipperary" title="County Tipperary">County Tipperary</a> was split into North and South <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Riding_(division)" title="Riding (division)">Ridings</a> in 1838. These Ridings were established as separate administrative counties under the Local Government (Ireland) Act, 1898.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/County_Dublin" title="County Dublin">County Dublin</a> was abolished as an administrative county in 1994, while also remaining a point of reference for purposes other than local government. Its territory was divided into three administrative counties: <a href="/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire%E2%80%93Rathdown" title="D√∫n Laoghaire‚ÄìRathdown">D√∫n Laoghaire‚ÄìRathdown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fingal" title="Fingal">Fingal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_Dublin" title="South Dublin">South Dublin</a>. The county borough of <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a>, together with the county boroughs of <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galway" title="Galway">Galway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Limerick" title="Limerick">Limerick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Waterford" title="Waterford">Waterford</a>, were re-styled as <a href="/wiki/City_council" title="City council">city councils</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_Act_2001" title="Local Government Act 2001">Local Government Act 2001</a>, with the same status in law as county councils.</p>
<p>The city councils of <a href="/wiki/Limerick" title="Limerick">Limerick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Waterford" title="Waterford">Waterford</a> were merged with their respective county councils by the <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_Reform_Act_2014" title="Local Government Reform Act 2014">Local Government Reform Act 2014</a>, to form new city and county councils. Anomalously, the city of <a href="/wiki/Kilkenny" title="Kilkenny">Kilkenny</a> does not have a "city council" as it was a <a href="/wiki/Borough" title="Borough">borough</a> but not a <a href="/wiki/County_borough" title="County borough">county borough</a>. It is now administered by its eponymous county council but is, exceptionally, permitted to retain the style of "city" for ornament only. Also, the 2014 Act abolished North Tipperary and South Tipperary, and re-established County Tipperary.</p>
<p>These 31 "county-level" entities correspond to the first level of <a href="/wiki/Local_administrative_unit" title="Local administrative unit">local administrative unit</a> for EU and <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> purposes. The second level of local administrative unit (LAU) is the <a href="/wiki/District_electoral_division" title="District electoral division">District electoral division</a>. Of the administrative structures established under the 1898 Local Government Act, the only type to have been completely abolished was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rural_District" title="Rural District">Rural District</a>, which was rendered void in the early years of the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> amidst widespread allegations of corruption. At a level above that of LAU is the <a href="/wiki/NUTS_2_statistical_regions_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="NUTS 2 statistical regions of the Republic of Ireland">Region</a> which clusters counties together for <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">NUTS</a> purposes. The Regions are administered by <a href="/wiki/Regional_Authorities_in_Ireland" title="Regional Authorities in Ireland">Regional Authorities</a> which were established by the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Local_Government_Act_1991&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Local Government Act 1991 (page does not exist)">Local Government Act 1991</a> and came into existence in 1994.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In 2013 <a href="/wiki/Education_and_Training_Board" title="Education and Training Board">Education and Training Boards</a> (ETBs) were formed throughout the Republic of Ireland, replacing the system of <a href="/wiki/Vocational_Education_Committee" title="Vocational Education Committee">Vocational Education Committees</a> (VECs) created in 1930. Originally, VECs were formed for each administrative county and county borough, and also in a number of larger towns. In 1997 the majority of town VECs were absorbed by the surrounding county. The 33 VEC areas were reduced to 16 ETB areas, with each consisting of one or more local government county or city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roinn_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-roinn-18">[17]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Institutes_of_technology_in_Ireland" title="Institutes of technology in Ireland">Institute of technology</a> system was organised on the committee areas or "functional areas", these still remain legal but are not as important as originally envisioned as the institutes are now more national in character and are only really applied today when selecting governing councils, similarly <a href="/wiki/Dublin_Institute_of_Technology" title="Dublin Institute of Technology">Dublin Institute of Technology</a> was originally a group of several colleges of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_of_Dublin" title="City of Dublin">City of Dublin</a> committee.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Elections">Elections</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Elections">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Where possible, <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_constituencies_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="Parliamentary constituencies in the Republic of Ireland">parliamentary constituencies in the Republic of Ireland</a> follow county boundaries. Under the Electoral Act 1997 a Constituency Commission is established following the publication of census figures every five years. The Commission is charged with defining constituency boundaries, and the 1997 Act provides that <i>the breaching of county boundaries shall be avoided as far as practicable</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> This provision does not apply to the boundaries between cities and counties, or between the three counties in the Dublin area.</p>
<p>This system usually results in more populated counties having several constituencies: Dublin, including Dublin city, is subdivided into twelve constituencies, Cork into five. On the other hand, smaller counties such as Carlow and Kilkenny or Laois and Offaly may be paired to form constituencies. An extreme case is the splitting of Ireland's least populated county of Leitrim between the constituencies of <a href="/wiki/Sligo%E2%80%93North_Leitrim_(D%C3%A1il_%C3%89ireann_constituency)" title="Sligo‚ÄìNorth Leitrim (D√°il √âireann constituency)">Sligo‚ÄìNorth Leitrim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roscommon%E2%80%93South_Leitrim_(D%C3%A1il_%C3%89ireann_constituency)" title="Roscommon‚ÄìSouth Leitrim (D√°il √âireann constituency)">Roscommon‚ÄìSouth Leitrim</a>.</p>
<p>Each county or city is divided into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Local_electoral_area" title="Local electoral area">Local electoral areas</a> for the election of councillors. The boundaries of the areas and the number of councillors assigned are fixed from time to time by order of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Minister_for_the_Environment,_Community_and_Local_Government" title="Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government">Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government</a>, following a report by the Local Government Commission, and based on population changes recorded in the census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Northern_Ireland">In Northern Ireland</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: In Northern Ireland">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="hatnote" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Counties of Northern Ireland">Counties of Northern Ireland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Local government in Northern Ireland">Local government in Northern Ireland</a></div>
<p>In Northern Ireland, a major reorganisation of local government in 1973 replaced the six traditional counties and two <a href="/wiki/County_borough" title="County borough">county boroughs</a> (<a href="/wiki/Belfast" title="Belfast">Belfast</a> and <a href="/wiki/Derry" title="Derry">Derry</a>) with 26 single-tier districts for local government purposes. In 2015, as a result of a <a href="/wiki/Reform_of_local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Reform of local government in Northern Ireland">reform process that started in 2005</a>, these districts were merged to form 11 new single-tier "super districts".</p>
<p>The six traditional counties remain in use for some purposes, including the three-letter coding of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_car_number_plates#Northern_Ireland" title="British car number plates">vehicle number plates</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Mail" title="Royal Mail">Royal Mail</a> <a href="/wiki/Postcode_Address_File" title="Postcode Address File">Postcode Address File</a> (which records counties in all addresses although they are no longer required for postcoded mail) and <a href="/wiki/Lord_Lieutenant#Northern_Ireland" title="Lord Lieutenant">Lord Lieutenancies</a> (for which the former county boroughs are also used). There are no longer official 'county towns'. However the counties are still very widely acknowledged, for example as administrative divisions for sporting and cultural organisations.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_uses">Other uses</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Other uses">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The administrative division of the island along the lines of the traditional 32 counties was also adopted by non-governmental and cultural organisations. In particular the <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association" title="Gaelic Athletic Association">Gaelic Athletic Association</a> continues to organise its activities on the basis of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GAA_county" title="GAA county">GAA counties</a> that, throughout the island, correspond almost exactly to the 32 traditional counties in use at the time of the foundation of that organisation in 1884. The GAA also uses the term "county" for some of its organisational units in Britain and further afield.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="List_of_counties">List of counties</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: List of counties">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The first 32 divisions listed below are the "traditional" counties, 21 of which still have administrative functions as local government divisions in the Republic of Ireland (in some cases with slightly redrawn boundaries). The newer administrative counties established in the Republic are listed at the foot of the table. The Irish-language names of counties in the Republic of Ireland are prescribed by ministerial order, which in the case of three newer counties, omits the word <i>contae</i> (county).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup> Irish names form the basis for all English-language county names except Dublin, Waterford, Wexford, and Wicklow, which are of Norse origin. The Ulster-Scot names are principally derived from the North/South Ministerial Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-NorthSouth-22">[21]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the "Region" column of the table below, except for the six Northern Ireland counties the reference is to <a href="/wiki/NUTS_3_statistical_regions_of_the_Republic_of_Ireland" title="NUTS 3 statistical regions of the Republic of Ireland">NUTS 3 statistical regions of the Republic of Ireland</a>. "<a href="/wiki/County_town" title="County town">County town</a>" is the current or former administrative capital of the county.</p>
<p>Cities which, in the Republic, are currently administered outside the county system, but with the same legal status as administrative counties, are not shown separately: these are <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dublin" title="Dublin">Dublin</a> and, <a href="/wiki/Galway" title="Galway">Galway</a>. Also not shown are the former <a href="/wiki/County_borough" title="County borough">county boroughs</a> of Londonderry and <a href="/wiki/Belfast" title="Belfast">Belfast</a> which in Northern Ireland had the same legal status as the six counties until the reorganisation of local government in 1973.</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable">

<td></td>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Whilst often today called English, a term which would not have been understood at the time, Henry II was in fact a Norman Frenchman, born in <a href="/wiki/Le_Mans" title="Le Mans">Le Mans</a> and spent most of his early life there. His accession, which was essentially by force from his mother's cousin Stephen, was the continuance of the Norman subjugation of England</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Londonderry is often called <i>Derry</i> ‚Äì see <a href="/wiki/Derry/Londonderry_name_dispute" title="Derry/Londonderry name dispute">Derry/Londonderry name dispute</a></span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">

<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Tully, James (19 October 1976). <a class="external text" href="http://www.irishstatutebook.ie:80/1976/en/act/prv/0001/print.html" rel="nofollow">"Local Government Provisional Order Confirmation Act, 1976"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Ireland" title="Attorney General of Ireland">Office of the Irish Attorney General</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">22 March</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACounties+of+Ireland&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rft.aulast=Tully&amp;rft.btitle=Local+Government+Provisional+Order+Confirmation+Act%2C+1976&amp;rft.date=1976-10-19&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishstatutebook.ie%3A80%2F1976%2Fen%2Fact%2Fprv%2F0001%2Fprint.html&amp;rft.pub=Office+of+the+Irish+Attorney+General&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;">¬†</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-roinn-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-roinn_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="http://www.education.ie/en/Press-Events/Press-Releases/2013-Press-Releases/PR-%202013-%2007-%2001.html" rel="nofollow">"01 July, 2013‚Äì Education and Training Boards replace VECs"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Education_and_Skills_(Ireland)" title="Department of Education and Skills (Ireland)">Department of Education and Skills</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 July</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACounties+of+Ireland&amp;rft.btitle=01+July%2C+2013%93+Education+and+Training+Boards+replace+VECs&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.education.ie%2Fen%2FPress-Events%2FPress-Releases%2F2013-Press-Releases%2FPR-%25202013-%252007-%252001.html&amp;rft.pub=Department+of+Education+and+Skills&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;">¬†</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.constituency-commission.ie/docs/act1997.pdf" rel="nofollow">Electoral Act 1997</a></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2001/en/act/pub/0037/sec0023.html" rel="nofollow">"Local Government Act 2001, Section 23"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Irish_Statute_Book" title="Irish Statute Book">Irish Statute Book</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 September</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACounties+of+Ireland&amp;rft.atitle=Local+Government+Act+2001%2C+Section+23&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishstatutebook.ie%2F2001%2Fen%2Fact%2Fpub%2F0037%2Fsec0023.html&amp;rft.jtitle=Irish+Statute+Book&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;">¬†</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2003/ga/si/0519.html" rel="nofollow">Ministerial Order, 2003</a> setting out Irish-language names</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-NorthSouth-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NorthSouth_22-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">North/South Ministerial Council. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130227120556/http://www.northsouthministerialcouncil.org/web_2006_ulster_scots_report.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Noarth/Sooth Cooncil o M√§nnyst√®rs"</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.northsouthministerialcouncil.org/web_2006_ulster_scots_report.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span> on 27 February 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 May</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACounties+of+Ireland&amp;rft.au=North%2FSouth+Ministerial+Council&amp;rft.btitle=Noarth%2FSooth+Cooncil+o+M%C3%A4nnyst%C3%A8rs&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.northsouthministerialcouncil.org%2Fweb_2006_ulster_scots_report.pdf&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;">¬†</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"><i>Gasait√©ar na h√âireann / Gazetteer of Ireland</i>. Dublin: Brainse Logainmneacha na Suirbh√©ireachta Ordan√°is / Placenames Branch of the Ordnance Survey. 1989. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>¬†<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7076-0076-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7076-0076-5">978-0-7076-0076-5</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACounties+of+Ireland&amp;rft.btitle=Gasait%C3%A9ar+na+h%C3%89ireann+%2F+Gazetteer+of+Ireland&amp;rft.date=1989&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7076-0076-5&amp;rft.place=Dublin&amp;rft.pub=Brainse+Logainmneacha+na+Suirbh%C3%A9ireachta+Ordan%C3%A1is+%2F+Placenames+Branch+of+the+Ordnance+Survey&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;">¬†</span></span></span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Counties_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: External links">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="border:1px solid #aaa;background-color:#f9f9f9">

<div id="First-level_administrative_divisions_in_European_countries" style="font-size:114%">First-level <a href="/wiki/Administrative_division" title="Administrative division">administrative divisions</a> in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> countries</div>
</th>
</tr>
<tr style="height:2px">
<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th class="navbox-group" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">Sovereign states</a></th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Albania" title="Municipalities of Albania">Albania</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Parishes_of_Andorra" title="Parishes of Andorra">Andorra</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/States_of_Austria" title="States of Austria">Austria</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Azerbaijan" title="Administrative divisions of Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a><sup><small>1</small></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Belarus" title="Regions of Belarus">Belarus</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Communities,_regions_and_language_areas_of_Belgium" title="Communities, regions and language areas of Belgium">Belgium</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Political_divisions_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Political divisions of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Bulgaria" title="Provinces of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">Croatia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Cyprus" title="Districts of Cyprus">Cyprus</a><sup><small>2</small></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_the_Czech_Republic" title="Regions of the Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Denmark" title="Regions of Denmark">Denmark</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Estonia" title="Counties of Estonia">Estonia</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Finland" title="Regions of Finland">Finland</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Regions_of_France" title="Regions of France">France</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Georgia_(country)" title="Administrative divisions of Georgia (country)">Georgia</a><sup><small>1</small></sup></li>

</td>
</tr>

<div class="navbox-abovebelow" style="padding:0.25em 0.5em;line-height:1.4em;font-size:85%;"><sup>1</sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">Has part of its territory</a> outside Europe. <sup>2</sup> Considered European for cultural, political and historical reasons but is geographically in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>.</div>
